item.title: Borderlands 4 Legendary Loot Drop Table
item.description:
There are 135+ Legendary weapons and items found in Borderlands 4 , and each of them can be obtained through the dedicated loot pool associated with 40 bosses. These bosses can be encountered and farmed after their specific battles during Main Missions, Side Missions, and Activities. We've listed every Legendary that you can get in Borderlands 4 , the boss you can get it from, and the location, so you can farm the weapon that you seek without getting lost and confused. Each boss has their location listed, when they can be farmed, and what loot they drop, so that you're in the know.

item.title: Best Tactical Games Where Every Decision Matters
item.description:
Summary

  • XCOM 2 forces long-term tactics due to dire consequences for mistakes.
  • Fire Emblem: Three Houses combines tactical battles with political choices.
  • Into the Breach requires precise moves to prevent catastrophic outcomes.

Everyone loves it when a plan comes together, and some games provide that dopamine rush in full force, except, they also make players suffer dire consequnces in case those plans fall through. In these worlds, a misplaced unit, a wasted turn, or a poorly timed action can snowball into disaster. These are the kinds of games that make players pause mid-move and mutter “this better work” under their breath.

From high-stakes espionage to sprawling battlefields, the following titles reward patience and punish recklessness. Here are a handful of great tactical games that push players into scenarios where strategy is more than a buzzword; it is survival. Sometimes, the cost of a wrong choice is not just failure, but the story itself bending in a direction that players cannot undo.

XCOM 2

When One Wrong Step Means Losing The War

XCOM 2

XCOM 2 demands long-term thinking in a way that feels almost cruel. Every squad member is valuable, and losing even one veteran can ripple through the rest of the campaign. Enemies adapt to tactics, forcing players to rethink strategies mid-battle. On top of the firefights, there’s the overarching resistance management, where resources are limited, and global alien influence grows if players fail to respond quickly.

Pemadeath means each mission becomes a mix of calculated risk and desperate improvisation. Choosing to extract early can save a team of soldiers but waste precious objectives. Staying too long might secure the win but cost a hero's life. Every decision pulls players between short-term survival and long-term success, making even victory feel like a gamble that only just paid off.

Fire Emblem: Three Houses

Choosing Sides Is Only Half The Battle

Fire Emblem: Three Houses

The classroom setting of Fire Emblem: Three Houses disguises just how brutal its tactical layer can be. The initial choice of house sets the stage for the story, but it’s the relationships and skill-building between missions that shape each army’s capabilities. A single recruitment or training decision made months earlier can decide whether a battle is winnable.

When war breaks out, those decisions can pay off or cause result in disaster. Permanent death for fallen soldiers in “Classic” mode means each move in combat carries the weight of losing not just a unit, but a friend that players saw grow from student to warrior. Story branches diverge sharply depending on allegiances, making the consequences of political and tactical choices feel inseparable.

Into The Breach

Chess With Rockets And Giant Bugs

Into the Breach

What looks like minimalist chess at first glance quickly becomes a science of crisis management in Into the Breach . Enemy moves are shown in advance, which shifts the tension from guessing to solving. The puzzle is in finding a sequence of moves that prevents catastrophic damage, often by making brutal sacrifices.

Units lost in one timeline can’t be recovered unless players send a pilot back in time, resetting the campaign but preserving one veteran. This roguelike structure makes even failed runs valuable, as hard lessons carry over. Each map is small, yet every square counts; a single misplaced mech can doom an entire city.

Triangle Strategy

Moral Dilemmas Wrapped In Hexes

Triangle Strategy
RPG
Tactical
Systems

Triangle Strategy plays like a political drama that happens to use a grid-based combat system. Choices made in dialogue are as impactful as choices during battle, thanks to the Scales of Conviction mechanic, which lets allies vote on critical decisions. Outcomes shift not only the story but the makeup of the player's army, with some characters only joining under certain ideological paths.

Combat itself rewards careful terrain use and coordinated attacks. Positioning a unit for a backstab or chaining elemental effects can swing the tide, but overextending can lead to sudden losses. The knowledge that both battlefield and council chamber decisions shape the outcome of any number of battles and narratives makes every choice feel permanent.

No one associates ogres with diplomacy, and rightfully so! The confusingly named Tactics Ogre: Reborn is a remake of a 1995 classic where players take control of Denam Pavel, a rebel fighter caught up in a civil war. The choices made off the battlefield matter just as much as those made mid-fight. Branching storylines react strongly to moral decisions, alliances, and betrayals. Players can find themselves fighting former allies simply because of a stance they took hours earlier.

On the tactical side, unit customization and terrain play a massive role. Elevation advantages, choke points, and weather effects can turn seemingly doomed encounters into hard-won victories. Yet every casualty feels permanent, both in terms of manpower and narrative weight. It’s a game where rewinding time is an option, but the pull to live with each mistake can be even stronger.

item.title: Best Open-World Games For Feeling Like A Hacker
item.description:
Summary

  • Hacking in open-world games often involves fun minigames, usually in the form of logic and number-based puzzles.
  • Games like GTA 5 and Saints Row 4 feature hacking in important missions.
  • Hacking mechanics in games like Cyberpunk 2077 and Deus Ex: Mankind Divided assist with stealth and offer diverse abilities.

Hacking is a somewhat mysterious practice to most of the general public, often portrayed in popular culture as a miraculous and fast-paced process that is akin to technical wizardry. Video games have run with this fantasy, utilizing hacking as a mechanic to gain access to new areas or simply manipulate the world in some way.

On many occasions, there are satisfying minigames that players must complete to succeed in a hack, which are usually in the form of simple logic or number-based puzzles. These are some of the best open-world games for feeling like a hacker, ranked based on a combination of their fun factor and just how important hacking is to the overall gameplay experience.

item.title: Treehouse Games’ Co-Founder Explains How Playtesting Helped Shape Voyagers of Nera
item.description:
Voyagers of Nera is an upcoming survival crafting game from developer Treehouse Games. It tasks players to explore the vastness of the ocean as they aim to build settlements, scavenge resources, and fight monsters. The game is largely intended to invoke that feeling of awe and wonder that only the ocean can achieve, and gameplay will take place both above and below the waves to reflect this.

Game Rant recently caught up with Treehouse Games CEO Michael Chu to learn more about Voyagers of Nera . He explained that one of the main reasons the game has evolved into what it is today is due to extensive playtesting from genre experts. He discussed the power of playtesting and how it can work wonders for the relationship between developer and player.

Voyagers of Nera Underwent Extensive Playtesting

It wasn't long after Treehouse Games began work on Voyagers of Nera that the studio realized bringing on external playtesters would be extremely beneficial. Building a survival crafting game set in the ocean presents some extensive challenges, ones that expert players are in a strong position to both point out and help developers overcome. Chu explained,

"We've tested the game with external players every two weeks since April 2024. When we started doing it, we were like, why did we decide to do it? This is so hard. It's so much work! But we had so many players who were so excited to give us rich feedback. It really let us build real relationships and real deep communication and nuance."

Genre Experts Provided Plenty of Feedback

While getting external playtesters midway through the development journey is all well and good, having the correct demographic on the task is crucial to ensuring feedback is relevant and actually useful. It would make little sense to have a group of FPS experts playtest a fighting game. When it came to Voyagers of Nera , Chu and his team ensured that playtesters were highly accustomed to survival crafting games, fully aware of the genre's strengths and, perhaps more importantly, its trappings. He said,

"We specifically looked to get feedback from people who are survival crafting diehards for this system. They’d be like, I like this system because it's more like my favorite game, but this other system I don't like, it's like this other system from this game, which really had these problems. That's the kind of conversations we have on the team. It was such a game-changer. Multiply that over thousands of people, over a year and a half, and man, that felt like it opened up so many doors for improving the game."

With Voyagers of Nera first releasing in early access, Treehouse Games having open lines of communication with its players will be key to ensuring the game improves and evolves as it works toward a full release. Chu and his team are counting on their players to help ensure the game isn't just a drop in the ocean that is the survival crafting genre.
